caption: The Arc de Triomphe is a true masterpiece of architecture and engineering. Its intricate carvings and sculptures, as well as its historical significance, make it one of the most iconic landmarks in Paris. Whether you admire it from below or climb to the top for breathtaking views, the Arc de Triomphe is a must-see attraction when visiting Paris.

The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, located beneath the Arc de Triomphe in Paris, is a solemn and enduring tribute to the countless soldiers who lost their lives in World War I, with their identities remaining unknown. This simple yet powerful memorial, marked by an eternal flame that is rekindled every evening, symbolizes the sacrifice and bravery of all soldiers who have fallen in the line of duty. The flame serves as a reminder of the ongoing respect and gratitude owed to those who fought for France‚Äôs freedom. Visiting the tomb evokes a deep sense of reflection and reverence, connecting the present with the past in a poignant and meaningful way.
A must landmark to visit when in Paris. t is one of the most beautiful piece of architecture at most famous street Champs Elysees.

The tomb of the unknown soldier of Paris is a solemn and moving tribute to the millions of French soldiers who died in the First World War. It is located under the Arc de Triomphe, one of the most iconic monuments of Paris, and it symbolizes the nation's gratitude and respect for those who sacrificed their lives for its freedom. The tomb contains the remains of an unidentified soldier, chosen among eight candidates from different battlefields, who represents all the fallen soldiers. The tomb is always adorned with flowers and flags, and it is guarded by veterans and military personnel. Every evening, at 6:30 pm, a ceremony takes place to rekindle the eternal flame that burns on the tomb. The flame was first lit in 1923 and has never been extinguished since then. The tomb of the unknown soldier of Paris is a must-see for anyone who wants to learn more about the history and culture of France, and to pay homage to its heroes.

It is a deeply emotional and meaningful place. Located under the majestic Arc de Triomphe, this tomb pays tribute to all the soldiers who fell in the First World War whose names were never known. The eternal flame, which is rekindled every night, is a powerful symbol of respect and memory.  When visiting, you feel a special connection to history and sacrifice, and it is difficult not to stop for a moment to reflect. In addition, it is an ideal point to enjoy the imposing view of the Arch and the axis of the Champs-Elys√©es.  An essential place for those who appreciate history and want to pay tribute to the courage of those who gave everything for their country. A site that invites reflection and reminds us of the value of peace.

Memorial grave for unidentified soldiers. At the foot of the Arc de Triomphe he always keeps the flame burning. It is an incredible place and a visit is almost obligatory since it is in one of the most famous monuments in Paris.

The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is a tomb dedicated to mourning unidentified soldiers who lost their lives in war. There are many countries with this kind of culture, and France seems to be one of them, with the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier located under the Arc de Triomphe in Etoile. The inscription on this grave dates from 1914 to 1918 AD, and it appears to be from World War I.  The shrine is still decorated with flowers to show respect for the dead, so it's a good idea to remember to pay your respects when visiting this place.

Visited around 11:00 on Wednesday, November 1, 2023  I have seen the Arc de Triomphe in various countries, The Arc de Triomphe in France is truly a sight to behold.  Although it is big, Because it is large, there is a lot of history at the time of its construction. It's complicated...  I can't stand it.  *************************** In 1806, Napoleon I ordered its construction to commemorate a military victory. Gate 49.54m high and 44.82m wide The walls are carved with depictions of Napoleon's battles and the march of volunteer troops. (La Marseillaise)  This gate is called the Arc de Triomphe (Bridge of Victory). represents the majesty of France  This Arc de Triomphe is also called the Arc de Triomphe. Commemorating the victory at the Battle of Austerlitz in 1805 Built by Napoleon It took 30 years to build, It was completed in 1836, more than ten years after Napoleon's death. ***************************

Like every country, France also has the monument to the unknown soldier, it is located under the Arc de Triomphe, you don't need a ticket to see the monument, but to go up to the Arc de Triomphe, you need a ticket.

Commemorative monument located at the foot of the Arc de Triomphe and freely visible to those passing through the area in the center of the square. It consists of a stone plaque and a brazier which is lit every evening at 6.30pm. The tomb holds one of the many soldiers of unknown identity who lost their lives during the First World War to defend the homeland and freedom of the French people. The soldier has been buried here since 11/11/1920, the anniversary of the peace between France and Germany and the date on which another unknown soldier was buried in Westminster. The flame of the brazier has been lit since 1923.

The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at the Arc de Triomphe is a symbol against war and a reminder of its victims. I waited behind a few others who wanted to photograph the tomb, from different countries and different ethnicities. Rarely have I felt such respect, no one pushed or complained, everyone thanked those behind me for their patience. Apparently they were also former soldiers who know what it means to have to risk their lives because a madman or criminal thinks that the neighboring country "belongs" to them too.

Grandchildren, primary school, history of Napoleon, revolution and the First World War told. It was quite busy on the square, we did not go on top of the Arc because we were already on the Eiffel Tower 2 days earlier.
